;;2023 年 3 月 13 日，欧洲旗帜在比利时布鲁塞尔的欧盟委员会总部外飘扬。REUTERS/Yves Herman/档案照片;两名欧盟高级官员周一对路透表示，在联合国调查发现援助物资存在广泛盗窃和滥用行为后，欧盟执行官已暂时停止向索马里世界粮食计划署（WFP）提供资金。旨在避免饥荒。

;

;根据联合国数据，欧盟委员会去年向粮食计划署在索马里的行动提供了超过 700 万美元的援助，仅占其收到的超过 10 亿美元捐款总额的一小部分.

;

;欧盟成员国在双边基础上提供了更多资金。目前尚不清楚是否也会暂停援助。

;

;欧盟委员会发言人巴拉兹·乌伊瓦里 (Balazs Ujvari) 既没有具体证实也没有否认临时暂停援助，但表示：“到目前为止，欧盟尚未获悉联合国合作伙伴认为欧盟资助的项目受到了财务影响。

;

;“尽管如此，我们将继续监控事态发展，并遵守对欺诈、腐败或不当行为的零容忍态度，”他说。

;

;粮食计划署没有立即回应置评请求。

;

;一位欧盟高级官员表示，这一决定是在联合国调查得出结论认为土地所有者、地方当局、安全部队成员和人道主义工作者都参与了窃取针对弱势群体的援助。

;

;这位不愿透露姓名的官员表示，在粮食计划署满足额外条件（包括审查合作伙伴的条件）后，将恢复援助。索马里的地面。第二位欧盟高级官员证实了这一点。

;

;第三位消息人士（也是欧盟官员）表示，委员会正在“与粮食计划署积极合作，解决系统性缺陷”，但表示没有暂停任何援助

;

;根据路透社看到的一份副本，7 月 7 日的报告是由联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯委托编写的，该报告被标记为“严格保密”。该报告的内容于周一由专注于国际发展的媒体 Devex 首次发表。

;

;报告援引国内流离失所者 (IDP) 的话说，他们被迫支付高达一半的现金援助他们在面临驱逐、逮捕或从受益人名单中取消登记的威胁时向掌权者收到了援助金。

;

;三个月前，世界粮食计划署和美国国际开发署 (USAID) ;暂停向邻国埃塞俄比亚提供粮食援助;，以应对捐款广泛转移的情况。; p>;

;据一位欧盟高级官员称，欧盟委员会通过世界粮食计划署向索马里和埃塞俄比亚捐款 1000 万欧元（1069 万美元），其中一部分由暂停支付。

;

;各国是索马里迄今为止最大的人道主义捐助者。去年，美国国际开发署发言人杰西卡·詹宁斯在一份声明中表示，美国正在努力了解资金转移的严重程度，该资金用于那里的人道主义救援行动，金额为 22 亿美元，其中一半以上是由它贡献的。并“已经采取措施保护受益人，并确保纳税人的钱按照预期用于造福索马里的弱势群体。”

;

;该机构一位不愿透露姓名的官员介绍了埃塞俄比亚的情况索马里的情况有所不同，美国国际开发署不打算暂停对后者的粮食援助。

;

;负责协调政府人道主义应对工作的索马里灾害管理办公室在周一的一份声明中表示，索马里当局致力于调查联合国报告的调查结果，同时指出当前的援助交付系统是在“政府渠道之外”运作的。

;

;古特雷斯办公室没有立即回应置评请求。

;

;捐助者提振去年，人道主义官员警告说，由于非洲之角数十年来最严重的干旱，饥荒迫在眉睫，因此向索马里提供了资金。

;

;根据官方数据，饥荒得到了避免，但多达 ;去年有 43,000 人死亡，其中一半是 5 岁以下儿童研究人员估计，这是干旱造成的。

;

;联合国报告并未试图量化被转移的援助金额，但表示其调查结果“表明索马里的援助交付后转移是普遍且系统性的”报告称，总的来说，调查人员从索马里 55 个国内流离失所者地点收集了数据，发现所有这些地点的援助都被转移。索马里约有 380 万人流离失所，这是世界上流离失所率最高的国家之一。

;

;几十年来，援助分配一直是索马里的一个问题，政府机构薄弱、伊斯兰叛乱造成的普遍不安全以及少数民族部落的边缘化。

;

;自 2011 年饥荒期间援助盗窃事件曝光以来，人道主义机构已将其大部分援助转为现金转移，一些官员称这种转移不太容易腐败。< /p>;

;联合国报告是最新证据，表明基于现金的系统也可能被利用。它确定了由所谓的“看门人”领导的各种肇事者，这些看门人来自当地占主导地位的氏族的有权有势的个人。

;

;这些看门人利用他们对进入营地和食品受益人名单的影响力来强迫国内流离失所者付款报告称。

;

;报告称，安全部队成员还通过恐吓、有时逮捕拒绝付款的人来发挥作用，而一些人道主义工作者则与看门人勾结，将被盗资金装入自己的口袋。

;

; p>;

;虽然目前已经避免了饥荒，但报告警告说，人道主义资金不足可能会危及脆弱的进展。

;

;;全球援助预算面临压力;，迄今为止，联合国表示今年索马里人道主义应对行动所需的 26 亿美元资金仅占 36%已获得资助。

;

;（1美元= 0.9355欧元）

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 06:55:04 +0800 Ford could face strike in Canada, adding to US labor pressurehttps://reuters.com/article/autos-labor-uaw/ford-could-face-strike-in-canada-adding-to-us-labor-pressure-idUSKBN30O0HF
;;2023-09-18T21:56:19Z;
;;
;;美国众议院民主党少数党领袖哈基姆·杰弗里斯 (Hakeem Jeffries) 在密歇根州福特汽车公司外与罢工的美国汽车工人联合会成员一起走在纠察线上美国密歇根州韦恩装配厂，2023 年 9 月 17 日。REUTERS/Rebecca Cook;
;

;福特汽车 ;(FN); 可能会在加拿大面临罢工，而几天前，该工会的美国工厂的工人工厂举行罢工。

;

;周五，美国汽车工人联合会针对福特、通用汽车;(GM.N); 和克莱斯勒母公司 Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);，目标是每家公司都有一个装配厂。

;

;加拿大工会 Unifor 与福特的合同将于周一晚上 11:59 到期，该工会表示“虽然我们仍留在谈判桌上”罢工的可能性随着时间的推移而增加。”

;

;福特在加拿大有两家发动机工厂，为在美国组装的 F 系列和 Super Duty 皮卡生产 V-8 发动机。该公司还在安大略省设有一家装配厂。

;

;加拿大工人罢工导致这些发动机工厂关闭，可能会削弱福特最赚钱的汽车在美国的生产，即使美国汽车工人联合会决定不下令卡车工厂罢工。肯塔基州；密歇根州迪尔伯恩；和密苏里州堪萨斯城。

;

;周一，美国汽车工人联合会和底特律汽车制造商之间的谈判继续进行，汽车工人因工资问题举行的罢工已持续第四天，几乎没有迹象表明达成协议有任何进展。大约 12,700 名工人正在美国三家工厂举行罢工。

;

;工会谈判代表以及通用汽车、福特和 Stellantis 的代表在周末举行了会谈，试图结束美国几十年来最雄心勃勃的工业劳工行动之一。周一，UAW 与 Stellantis 举行了会谈，但没有达成任何协议。该公司已安排在下午晚些时候与福特进行新一轮谈判。

;

;一位发言人周一表示，Stellantis 正在考虑其位于底特律北部密歇根州奥本山的庞大总部大楼的选择。该公司不需要该综合体中的空间，该综合体曾经是前克莱斯勒公司的总部和技术中心，现在许多员工全部或部分时间远程工作。

;

;UAW 总裁 Shawn Fain 告诉我们NPR 周一表示，“周末的对话很少，所以球在他们的手中......我们还有很长的路要走。”

;

;他说，当被要求时，UAW 已准备好做必要的事情本周是否会将罢工扩大到其他工厂。

;

;在 MSNBC 的另一次采访中，费恩表示谈判进展缓慢：“我们将在接下来的几天里看看事态进展如何，以及我们是否必须扩大规模加大压力，这就是我们要做的。”

;

;财政部长珍妮特·耶伦表示，现在预测罢工对经济的影响还为时过早，这将取决于行动持续多长时间以及受影响的范围.

;

;罢工导致密歇根州、俄亥俄州和密苏里州的工厂停产，这些工厂生产福特野马、吉普牧马人和雪佛兰科罗拉多以及其他受欢迎的车型。

;

;福特周五让 600 名员工休假。由于停工的影响，密歇根野马工厂的工人没有举行罢工。通用汽车表示，由于附近的密苏里州工厂发生罢工，预计本周初将停止其堪萨斯汽车工厂的运营，影响到 2,000 名工人。

;

;分析师预计工厂将生产利润更高的皮卡，例如福特 F-150如果罢工继续下去，通用汽车的雪佛兰索罗德和 Stellantis 的 Ram 将成为下一个罢工目标。

;

;博思格钢铁的股票 ;(BSL.AX); 跌至三个多月低点。这家澳大利亚钢铁制造商 2023 财年近 42% 的销售收入来自北美。

;

;工会和公司在工人的工资和福利问题上存在争执。三大汽车制造商提议在其拟议交易的 4-1/2 年期限内加薪 20%，但这只是 UAW 到 2027 年要求的一半。UAW 在谈判期间一度提出降低要求至 36%。

;

;除了提高工资外，UAW 还要求缩短工作周、恢复固定福利养老金以及随着汽车制造商转向电动汽车而加强工作保障。

; Tue, 19 Sep 2023 06:25:03 +0800 Stocks slip, US yields steady but growth outlook dimshttps://reuters.com/article/global-markets/stocks-slip-us-yields-steady-but-growth-outlook-dims-idUSKBN30O00K

;

;全球股市下跌，周一 10 年期国债收益率接近 16 年高点，原因是市场担忧加剧美联储关于利率的长期较高信息将对美国消费者造成影响。

;

;油价上涨，可能;政府在不到两周内关闭;和美国汽车工人联合会罢工;底特律三大汽车制造商;都可能放缓仍强劲运行的美国经济通货膨胀速度太快。

;

;“人们对经济感到担忧，这与利率、联邦基金利率的上升直接相关。这使得人们买房、买房变得更加困难Ingalls & Snyder 的高级投资组合策略师 Tim Ghriskey 表示：“尽管市场在美联储周三结束为期两天的政策会议时已经对加息进行了折算，但这种可能性仍然存在。”未来仍有可能再次加息。

;

;“美联储不太可能在本次会议上加息，”Ghriskey 表示。但我认为他们正处于每隔一次会议加息的周期，除非我们真的看到通胀显着改善。”

;

;随着油价进一步飙升，全球原油基准布伦特原油价格接近每桶 95 美元。由于美国经济的韧性和 8 月份关键通胀数据显示出减速趋势，市场对上周的飙升不以为然。

;

;但油价上涨将挤压消费者，尤其是在学生贷款恢复的情况下。纽约 Bannockburn Global Forex 首席市场策略师马克·钱德勒 (Marc Chandler) 表示，10 月将支付更多款项。

;

;“油价上涨是对消费的征税，”钱德勒说。“自 70 年代以来的大多数经济衰退发生在石油危机之后，主要是石油价格翻倍。”

;

;基准 10 年期国债收益率为 4.3125%，略低于 8 月 22 日达到的 4.366% 水平，两年期国债收益率进一步升至 5% 以上。

;

;虽然期货显示美联储周三加息的可能性仅为 1%，但市场预计美联储将维持隔夜贷款利率高于到 2024 年 7 月下旬，通胀率仍将保持在 5% 的水平。

;

;“由于通胀率仍远高于美联储 2% 的目标，尽管市场有最强烈的愿望，但在降息之前肯定更有可能再次加息。” Nuveen 首席投资官 Saira Malik 在一份报告中表示。

;

;MSCI 对全球股票的衡量;(.MIWD00000PUS);收盘下跌0.24%。泛欧 STOXX 600 指数 ;(.STOXX); 下跌 1.05%，受到下调的打击法国兴业银行新任首席执行官提出的备受期待的战略计划令投资者失望，其股价暴跌 12.05%，增长前景不容乐观。

;

;法国 ;第三大上市银行;表示，在其备受期待的战略计划中，预计未来几年的年销售额几乎不会增长。新任首席执行官。

;

;在伦敦，;以出口为主的富时 100 指数; ;(.FTSE); 发布了其这是一个多月来最糟糕的一天，汽车和零部件下跌 6.1%，下跌 0.8%。

;

;华尔街主要股指在交易日的大部分时间里上下波动，以在收盘时勉强维持名义涨幅。道琼斯工业平均指数 ;(.DJI); 上涨 0.02%，标准普尔 500 指数 ;(.SPX); 上涨 0.07%，纳斯达克综合指数 ;(.IXIC);小幅上涨0.01%。

;

;中国房地产困境、地缘政治紧张局势和持续罢工也加剧了对全球增长的担忧。

;

;房地产开发商中国恒大集团的股票;(3333警方拘留了其财富管理部门的部分员工后，周一股价暴跌 25%。同为开发商碧桂园 ;(2007.HK); ;面临另一次流动性测试;，最后期限是支付 1500 万美元的利息到离岸债券。

;

;中国的消失国防部长;加剧了习近平主席在国际参与方面立场的不确定性。

;

;全球央行占据中心舞台，其中五个监管 10 种交易最频繁货币的央行本周举行了利率制定会议。包括土耳其和南非在内的一系列新兴市场央行也将召开会议。

;

;周四，英国央行预计将进行第 15 次加息，并将基准借贷成本提高至 5.5%。

;

; >;

;日本央行是周五的关键风险事件。在最近的;行长上田一夫的言论;推高了收益率。

;

;周一，几天前，瑞典克朗兑欧元汇率跌至历史新低预计瑞典央行将再次加息。

;

;

;欧元上周因欧洲央行暗示可能加息而跌至 3-1/2 个月低点 1.0632 美元，随后上涨约 0.30% 至 1.069 美元。

;

;

;Ford Motor ;(FN); could face a strike in Canada if no agreement is reached by 11:59 pm Monday with the union representing about 5,600 Canadian auto workers, just days after workers at one of its US plants went on strike.

;

;On Friday, the United Auto Workers union launched a targeted strike against Ford, General Motors ;(GM.N); and Chrysler-parent Stellantis ;(STLAM.MI);, targeting one assembly plant at each company.

;

;Canadian union Unifor, whose contract with Ford expires at 11:59 pm Monday, said "while we remain at the table the likelihood of a strike increases with each passing hour."

;

;Ford has two engine plants in Canada that build V-8 motors for F-series and Super Duty pickups assembled in the United States. It also has an assembly plant in Ontario.

;

;A walkout by Canadian workers that shut down those engine plants could cripple US production of Ford's most profitable vehicles, even if the UAW decides not to order walkouts at truck plants in Kentucky; Dearborn, Michigan; and Kansas City, Missouri.

;

;Separately, about 12,700 US auto workers are on strike as part of a ;labor action; targeting three US assembly plants - one at each of the Detroit Three - after the prior four-year labor agreements expired.

;

;Talks between the UAW and the Detroit automakers continued on Monday as a strike by auto workers over pay dragged on for a fourth day with little sign of progress toward a deal.

;

;Union negotiators and representatives of GM, Ford and Stellantis held talks over the weekend in an attempt to end one of the most ambitious US industrial labor actions in decades.周一，UAW 与 Stellantis 举行了会谈，但没有达成任何协议。 It had scheduled a new round of talks with Ford for late afternoon.

;

;UAW President Shawn Fain told NPR Monday there were "minimal conversations over the weekend so the ball is in their court .... We have a long way to go."

;

;He said the UAW is ready to do what was necessary when asked whether it would extend the strike to other plants this week.

;

;In a separate MSNBC interview, Fain said talks were moving slowly: "We'll see how things progress the next few days and if we have to amp up pressure that is what we're going to do."

;

;Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said it was premature to forecast the strike's impact on the economy, which would depend on how long the action lasted and what was affected.

;

;The strikes have halted production at plants in Michigan, Ohio and Missouri that produce the Ford Bronco, Jeep Wrangler and Chevrolet Colorado, alongside other popular models.

;

;Ford on Friday told 600 workers that are not on strike at the Michigan Bronco plant that they should not come to work indefinitely because of the impact of the work stoppage. GM says it expects to halt operations at its Kansas car plant early this week because of the strike at its nearby Missouri plant, affecting 2,000 workers.

;

;Analysts expect plants that build more profitable pickup trucks like Ford's F-150, GM's Chevy Silverado and Stellantis's Ram to be the next strike targets if the walkout continues.

;

;Shares of BlueScope Steel ;(BSL.AX); slipped to an over three-month low as the strike weighs on its North American business. The Australian steelmaker generated nearly 42% of its fiscal 2023 sales revenue from North America.

;

;The unions and companies are at loggerheads over pay and benefits for workers. The three automakers have proposed 20% raises over the 4-1/2 year term of their proposed deals, though that is only half of what the UAW is demanding through 2027. The UAW at one point during the talks offered to lower its demand to 36%.

;

;Besides higher wages, the UAW is also demanding shorter work weeks, restoration of defined benefit pensions and stronger job security as automakers make the shift to electric vehicles.

;;Haitians work on the construction site of a water channel from the Massacre river, a river shared between Haiti and the Dominican Republic, after Dominican President Luis Abinader announced a total border shutdown amid a conflict over the construction of the channel, in Ouanaminthe, Haiti September 15, 2023. REUTERS/Octavio Jones/File Photo;
;

;A United Nations human rights expert called on the Dominican Republic and Haiti to resume talks to reach a quick, peaceful end to a total border shutdown launched by Dominican authorities on Friday, citing humanitarian and trade impacts.

;

;UN expert for Haiti William O'Neill said on Monday the closure would impact jobs and businesses that depend on cross-border trade and have "dire" results on access to essential goods in Haiti, which is already facing a humanitarian crisis.

;

;He called on the countries to seek international arbitration if needed.

;

;"Directors of medical clinics in Haiti have told me that they will not be able to care for their patients if access to the Dominican Republic is cut off," O'Neil said in a statement.

;

;"Lives are at stake," he added, noting that at least a quarter of food is imported through the border and calling on the Dominican Republic to allow the delivery of all ;humanitarian assistance; and essential goods.

;

;Dominican President Luis Abinader, who is seeking reelection in May 2024, ;announced the border shutdown ;last week, citing a canal being built on the Haitian side of a shared river that he says violates a 1929 treaty.

;

;Haiti's government has condemned the shutdown, which comes amid a worsening humanitarian crisis in the country driven by escalating gang warfare.

;

;The United Nations has repeatedly raised concerns about forced deportations of Haitians from the Dominican Republic, including of children and pregnant women.

;

;Dominican authorities said in a statement on Monday that water authority INDRHI had carried out an inspection of irrigation infrastructure in the border region near the canal and found no risk for local producers.

;

;INDRHI is continuing studies for construction of a dam ordered by Abinader, it said. Abinader last week said he was planning to build two dams that could "significantly affect" Haiti if the treaty is not active.

;

;In a national address late on Sunday, Abinader reaffirmed that the canal posed environmental risks and the measures would stay in place until its construction stopped definitively.

;Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said his nation's security agencies have ;actively pursued credible allegations; of a potential link between the Indian government and the June murder of a Sikh separatist leader and Canadian citizen, Hardeep Singh Nijjar, in Canada.

;

;Trudeau's comments on Monday marked the latest strain in relations between Ottawa and New Delhi this year.

;

;Canada has the highest population of Sikhs outside their home state of Punjab in India, and the country has been the site of many protests that have irked India.

;

;Here are some recent examples of uneasy ties between the two countries:

;

;Sept 2023: Canadian Trade Minister Mary Ng ;postponed a trade mission; to India planned for October. Both countries said they ;paused trade talks; after expressing earlier in 2023 they aimed to seal an initial trade deal this year.

;

;Bilateral commercial relations between the two countries are worth $100 billion, which includes $70 billion of Canadian portfolio investment, according to Indian figures.

;

;Sept 2023: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi ;conveyed strong concerns; about protests in Canada against India to Trudeau on the sidelines of the G20 summit in New Delhi.

;

;While a Sikh insurgency was suppressed in India in the 1990s, authorities have been wary of any revival of agitation, with a particular focus on small groups of Sikhs in Canada, who support the separatist demand and occasionally stage protests outside Indian embassies.

;

;June 2023: India's foreign minister, S. Jaishankar, ;hit out at Canada; for allowing a float in a parade depicting the 1984 assassination of then-Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi by her bodyguards, perceived to be glorification of violence by Sikh separatists.

;

;Indira Gandhi was assassinated in 1984 by two Sikh bodyguards after she allowed the storming of the holiest Sikh temple, aimed at flushing out Sikh separatists who demanded an independent homeland to be known as Khalistan. The storming of the temple had angered Sikhs around the world.

;

;March 2023: India ;summoned Canada's High Commissioner; to convey concern over pro-Khalistan protesters in Canada who breached the security of India's diplomatic mission and consulates.

;

;CONTEXT:

;

;Canada is home to an influential Sikh community and Indian leaders say there are some fringe groups there that are still sympathetic to the cause of an independent Sikh state, carved out of India.

;

;The Sikh insurgency of the 1980s and 1990s killed some 30,000 people. Sikh militants were blamed for the 1985 bombing of an Air India Boeing 747 flying from Canada to India in which all 329 people on board were killed.

;

;In 2018, Trudeau ;assured India; that Canada would not support anyone trying to revive a separatist movement in India but he has repeatedly said he respects the right to free speech and assembly of protesters to demonstrate.
